questions.text: Most common initiating factor in acute appendicitis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Luminal obstruction in the form of fecolith is the most common initiating factor for acute appendicitis. This causes increased intraluminal pressure which hampers lymphatic, venous and arterial drainage and leads to ischemia of the appendix. Bacterial infection is not the most common cause of appendicitis, organism which is most commonly isolated from a perforated appendix specimen is bacteroides. Lymphatic hyperplasia may compress the base of appendix and lead to appendicitis but it is not the most common cause . Perforation is a complication of appendicitis and not the cause .

questions.text: When acute appendicitis is suspected, it can be confirmed by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, B, C, & D) The diagnosis of acute appendicitis is mainly by clinical examination. USG is the investigation of choice to diagnose acute appendicitis in children. CT scan is best to diagnose acute appendicitis and appendicular lump. Blood counts also help in the diagnosis of acute appendicitis and there is increased leukocyte count in peripheral smear. Upper GI endoscopy has no role in the diagnosis of acute appendicitis.

choices.text: Common in people with fecolith obstruction
Appendectomy is done always in presence of rupture

questions.text: True about appendicular rupture is all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Even if you start early antibiotic therapy in patients of acute appendicitis it does not ensure prevention of appendicular rupture. Option A is true as appendicular rupture is more common in extremes of ages. Option B is correct as fecolith is the most common initiating factor for acute appendicitis, it predisposes patients to appendicular rupture. Option D is also correct in all patients of appendicular rupture you have to do an exploratory laparotomy and proceed with appendectomy.

questions.text: In a case of retrocecal appendicitis which movement aggravates pain? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This question is asking you about Psoas sign of acute appendicitis. It states that in patients with retrocecal appendicitis hyperextention of hip joint causes pain.

questions.text: Earliest symptom in acute appendicitis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pain is the earliest symptom of acute appendicitis, pain is around the periumbilical area and is because of distension of the appendix as appendix is derived from midgut. Slowly there occurs periappendicular fluid accumulation which irritates the parietal peritoneum and causes pain at Mc burney’s Point. Fever is a symptom which is present in patients of acute appendicitis but it is not the earliest symptom. Vomitting occurs in patients of acute appendicitis but it usually follows appearance of pain. Increased pulse rate is another feature found in patients of acute appendicitis.

questions.text: When the rectum is inflated with air through a rectal tube, pain and tenderness occur in the right iliac fossa in case of appendicitis? This is known as:(LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Bastedo’s sign describes a condition in which if rectum is inflated with air through rectal tube pain and tenderness occurs in right iliac fossa in case of acute appendicitis. Aaron’s sign is also present in acute appendicitis and is described as pain occurring on pressing of epigastric region. Battle sign is a feature which we see in middle cranial fossa base of skull fracture, in this there is bluish discolouration of the posterior part of the mastoid process. Mc burney’s sign is a feature seen in acute appendicitis and describes a migratory pain in patients of acute appendicitis in right iliac fossa .

choices.text: Tension gangrene due to the accumulating secretions

questions.text: The frequent mechanism in perforation of appendix is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute appendicitis is most commonly caused by obstruction of the lumen of appendix with the fecolith which leads to accumulation of secretions in the appendix and distention leading to impaired venous drainage, lymphatic drainage and arterial drainage, this ultimately results in ischemia of the appendix and can lead to perforation. Option A is false as even though fecolith is responsible for the initiation of appendicitis, it is not a direct cause for perforation, the tension which develops in the appendix lumen due to accumulation of fluid and secretions inside the lumen is the actual cause for perforation. Option C and D are not related to appendicular perforation.

questions.text: All are useful in acute appendicitis except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A is correct as antibiotics are started in acute appendicitis in early stage to bring the bacterial load under control and also control the systemic manifestations of the disease. Option B is correct as analgesics are given in patients of acute appendicitis as a supportive measure Option C is also correct as we need to keep the patient nil per oral during the medical treatment of the disease and during this time we need to give iv fluids to the patient . Option D is wrong as purgation has no role in the management of a patient with acute appendicitis.

choices.text: When appendicular perforation occurs early (within 24 hours)

questions.text: Diffuse peritonitis following appendicitis is usually seen: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) When appendicular perforation occurs early within 24 hours omentum doesnt get time to reach the site of inflammation and because of perforation the infective material spreads at all the places in the peritoneal cavity leading to diffuse peritonitis. Option B If perforation occurs late that is after 24 hours peritoneum mostly reaches the site of perforation and surrounds the infective material leading to the formation of something which is known as appendicular abscess. Option C Obstructive and non obstructive appendicitis has nothing to do with presence or absence of diffuse peritonitis after perforation. Option D is wrong as antibiotics have no effect on the occurance of perforation in case of acute appendicitis.

questions.text: Rovsing sign is seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rovising sign is present in acute appendicitis and described as when we press in left iliac fossa in a patient of acute appendicitis pain is felt in right iliac fossa . We do not see rovsing sign in acute cholecystitis and pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 15-years old boy is admitted with a history and physical finding consistent with appendicitis. Which of the following findings is most likely to be positive?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Iliopsoas sign is seen in patients of acute appendicitis and is positive when patient has retrocaecal appendix. When patient is asked to hyperextend the hip in patient experiences pain.

questions.text: Alvorado scoring in appendicitis includes all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D & E) Alvorado scoring is used in patients of acute appendicitis. It is used for predicting the presence or absence of acute appendicitis in patients who are suspected on clinical examination. Alvarado score consists of : M: Migratory pain A: Anorexia N: Nausea T: Tenderness R: Rebound tenderness E: Elevated temperature L: Leukocytosis S: Shift to left Every character is given one point only tenderness and leucocytosis are given two points. So Option D is false as leukopenia is not a feature of ALVORADO score it should be leucocytosis Option E is also wrong as it should be shift to left

questions.text: Most common occurrence before appendicitis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most of the appendicitis are initiated because of blockage of lumen by a fecolith as the initiating feature. Ileitis is not the cause for the initiation of acute appendicitis. Gastroenteritis can not lead to appendicitis. Perforation is a complication not a cause of acute appendicitis.

questions.text: In appendicitis, the initial periumbilical pain is eventually localized to right iliac fossa because of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pain is the earliest symptom of acute appendicitis, pain is around the periumbilical area and is because of distension of the appendix as appendix is derived from midgut. Slowly there occurs periappendicular fluid accumulation which irritates the parietal peritoneum and causes pain at Mc burney’s Point.

questions.text: "Ten horn" sign is a feature of: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ten Horn sign is seen in acute appendicitis. What we get in this is on pulling the right side testis in a patient of acute appendicitis patient experiences pain. Rectus muscle hematoma presents with a midline swelling in the abdomen which basically has fullness not a gross lump. Acute pancreatitis is associated with pain in the epigastric region radiating to the back, we get cullens sign in acute pancreatitis which is basically discolouration around the periumbilical region. Choledocholithiasis presents with a colicky abdominal pain in right hypochondrium.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms produces signs and symptoms that mimic acute appendicitis? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Yersinia enterocilitis leads to mesenteric lymphadenitis and it mimics acute appendicitis. It is very common in children and poses a great problem in diagnosis of this condition. Option A is false as E.coli can cause diarrhoea but not appendicitis. Option B is wrong as enterobius vermicularis causes perianal itching.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for acute appendicitis in children: (AIIMS November 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Investigation of choice for acute appendicitis in children is USG examination . CT scan is better than USG to diagnose appendicitis and more importantly to distinguish between appendicular abscess and appendicular lump. MRI is not an investigation of choice for acute appendicitis, it can be helpful but rarely used. X-ray abdomen standing is used in a patient of acute appendicitis to rule out appendicular perforation, xrays do not help in diagnosing acute appendicitis.

choices.text: Branch of lower division of ileocolic artery

questions.text: All are true about appendicular artery except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Appendicular artery supplies appendix , it is an end artery, and is a branch of iliocolic artery. Appendicular artery does not supply ileum .

questions.text: Ochsner-Sherren regime is used in management of: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ochsner sherren regimen is a method of conservative management in patients of appendicular mass, the reason being if we operate in a patient of appendicular lump there is high chance of development of caecal fistula. Option A Is wrong, as appendicular abscess is a D/d of appendicular lump and if it present as appendicular abscess needs to be drained. Option B is wrong as we do not follow ochsner sherren regimen for chronic appendicitis, In this we go for appendectomy. Option D is also wrong as in patients of acute appendicitis we have to go for appendectomy.

questions.text: A 26-years old male presented with 4 day history of pain in the right sided lower abdomen with frequent vomiting.Patients general condition is fair and clinically a tender lump was felt in the right iliac fossa. Most appropriate management for this case would be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This a clinical case scenario describing appendicular lump so in this we will follow an Ochsner sherren regimen which is basically a treatment option in which we we admit the patient, keep him nil per oral and give antibiotics, and we monitor temperature and pulse rate at serial intervals, if the patient improves we continue this treatment and then call the patient for interval appendectomy. Option A and B is wrong as we do not operate in the patients of appendicular lump as if we do an appendectomy there is a high chance of development of a ceacal fistula. Option D is also wrong as external drainage is a treatment option for an appendicular abscess.

questions.text: Grid-iron incision was first described by: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Grid iron incision is a muscle splitting incision given at the McBurney’s point perpendicular to the spinoumbilical line. Grid iron incision is also called a McBurney’s incision or Mc Arthur’s incision as it was first described by Mc Arthur. Grid iron incision is a muscle splitting incision If we cut the muscle fiber’s laterally which are basically muscle fiber’s of conjoint tendon then it is called as a Rutherford morrison’s incision. Rutherford Morrison incision is a muscle cutting incision. Lanz incision is a cosmetically preferred incision along the skin crease and it is a muscle splitting incision. It is used for appendectomy

questions.text: Stump size in appendectomy should not be more than
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) While operating a patient of appendectomy the stump size should not be more than 3 mm because if it is more than 3 mm then there is increased chance of stumpitis in these patients. Stumpitis is a condition where there is inflammation in the residual stump and if it develops patient may still have pain in the right hypochondrium similar to appendicitis.

questions.text: The nerve commonly damaged during McBurney's incision is: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Iliohypogastric nerve is most commonly injured in McBurney’s incision and as this nerve is damaged it can lead to the formation of inguinal hernia in later stages of life. Subcostal, 11th thoracic and 10th thoracic nerves are not damaged in McBurney’s incision.

choices.text: Most suitable if the diagnosis of appendicitis is definite
If it is converted into a muscle cutting incision it is called Rutherford Morison's incision
Inguinal hernia is a sequele of the incision
The incision can be extended upwards or downwards

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true of McBurney's incision? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A is correct, Mc Burney’s point denotes the point of the base of the appendix and if diagnosis of acute appendicitis is confirmed then McBurney;’s incision is most suitable. Option B is correct, if we cut the muscle fibers of conjoint tendon which lie laterally to the McBurney’s incision line, this modified incision is called Rutherford morrison’s incision and this is a muscle cutting incision. Option C is correct as the most common nerve injured in McBurney’s incision is iliohypogastric nerve and this predisposes to the formation of inguinal hernia. Option D is wrong as we can not extend the McBurney’s incision upward and downwards.

choices.text: Cutting the muscles medially into the rectus sheath
Incising vertically along the rectus muscle

questions.text: A Grid iron incision becomes a Rutherford Morrison's incision is extended by: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Grid iron incision is a muscle splitting incision given at the McBurney’s point perpendicular to the spinoumbilical line. Grid iron incision is also called a McBurney’s incision or Mc Arthur’s incision. If we cut the muscle fiber’s laterally which are basically muscle fiber’s of conjoint tendon then it is called as a Rutherford morrison’s incision. Rutherford Morrison incision is a muscle cutting incision.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a muscle-splitting incision? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lanz incision is a cosmetically preferred incision along the skin crease and it is a muscle splitting incision. It is used for appendectomy. Kocher’s incision is a right subcostal incision which is used for cholecystectomy and it is a muscle cutting incision. Rutherford Morrison incision is a muscle cutting incision used for appendectomy. Pfannenstiel incision is also a muscle cutting incision.

questions.text: What is the treatment of patient with carcinoid tumor of appendix of size more than 2 cm? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Carcinoid tumors are the most common malignancy of appendix Managemnt of Carcinoid tumor in appendix : If Carcinoid tumors are less than 1 cm in size then only appendectomy is sufficient. If Carcinoid tumor is more than 2 cm in size we have to subject the patient to right hemicolectomy If Carcinoid tumour is between 1 to 2 cm then we have to consider the following condition: 1.If it involves base, if it involves mesoappendix or if the lymph nodes are involved then we have to subject the patient to right hemicolectomy 2. If it does not involve the base, if meso appendix is not involved and if no lymphnode enlargement is present we can do only appendectomy in these patients.

questions.text: Most common tumor occurring in appendix: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Carcinoid tumors are the most common tumour of appendix and most common site which is involved is the tip of the appendix Adenocarcinoma also occurs in appendix but they are not the most common tumors . Melanoma involving the appendix is very rare.

choices.text: A computed tomographic (CT) scan with a nonvisualized appendix.
A barium enema where a short (2 cm) appendix was clearly identified.
An ultrasound study with a compressible appendix that is <5 mm in diameter
A C scan showing an edematous but retrocecal appendix.

questions.text: What imaging finding would exclude appendicitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The appendix is identified as a nonperistaltic, blind ending loop of bowel. The compressibility and anteroposterior dimensions are measured. Thickening of the wall as well as peri-appendiceal fluid with a non-compressible appendix are suggestive of appendicitis while an easily compressible, narrow appendix excludes the diagnosis. Failure to identify the appendix on imaging does not definitely rule out appendicitis.

questions.text: Which of the following physical signs is being demonstrated?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Rovsing sign is RLQ pain that is induced by palpation of the left lower quadrant and is highly suggestive of a RLQ inflammatory process. Dunphy sign elicits pain with coughing and is related to inflammation of the peritoneum. The obturator sign occurs with internal rotation of the right hip. Lastly, the iliopsoas sign is pain with extension of the right hip, attributed to a retrocecal appendix.

questions.text: A 19 year – old – male patient presents with pain abdomen in the right lower quadrant, with tenderness and rebound tenderness in the right iliac fossa on palpation. He has a history of anorexia and migration of pain. His total leukocyte count is 16,000/µl with 90% neutrophils. He has no history of nausea/ vomiting or fever. What is his total Alvarado score?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

choices.text: Appendiceal diameter >2.5 cm or surrounding soft tissue thickening
Lack of contrast filling the appendix
1-cm mass at the base of the appendix

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with RLQ pain. A CT scan is performed. What finding on CT scan is most suggestive of appendiceal lymphoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lymphoma of the appendix is uncommon. The most common types of appendiceal lymphoma in decreasing order are non-Hodgkin, Burkitt, and leukemia. Findings on CT scan include appendiceal diameter of>2.5 cm or surrounding soft tissue thickening. The management is confined to appendectomy. Right hemicolectomy is indicated if the tumor extends beyond the appendix onto the cecum or into the mesentery.

choices.text: Displaced to the right upper quadrant
Extraperitoneal and lying anterior to the cecum

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is suspected of having acute appendicitis. On physical examination his abdomen is soft and nondistended. He does not have pain with coughing or reproduction of tenderness in the right lower quadrant when palpated in the left lower quadrant. He experiences abdominal pain during extension of the right thigh while lying on his left side. He does not have pain with passive rotation of his right hip in a flexed position. Where do you suspect the location of the tip of his appendix to be?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The psoas sign is elicited by extension of the right thigh with the patient lying in the left lateral decubitus position. The stretched psoas muscle may irritate an inflamed overlying appendix and suggest retrocecal appendicitis. The obturator sign is elicited with passive external rotation of the flexed right hip. If positive, the obturator sign suggests that the inflamed tip is lying in the pelvis.

choices.text: Treat with antibiotics in an attempt to avoid an operation.
Obtain a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and proceed with an appendectomy if positive

questions.text: A 30-year-old, 28-week pregnant female presents to the emergency department with a 24-h history of right upper quadrant abdominal pain. The white blood cell (WBC) count is 18,000. An ultrasound was done showing a normal gallbladder and viable fetus. The appendix was not visualized. What is the next best step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Appendicitis occurs with equal frequency in both pregnant and nonpregnant women. Peritonitis may result in fetal loss. Diagnosing appendicitis during pregnancy can be difficult because abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and elevated WBC count are common during pregnancy. Additionally, as the uterus enlarges, the location of the appendix is shifted superiorly and medially. Delayed diagnosis and therefore delay in the treatment leading to perforated appendicitis increases the risk of fetal loss to about 30%. Ultrasound is helpful in establishing the diagnosis. In cases where ultrasound is equivocal, an MRI can be performed for further evaluation without the risk of radiation exposure to the developing fetus. A fairly aggressive approach with early laparoscopic exploration is a reasonable option in pregnant women with suspected appendicitis. The risk of maternal and/or fetal morbidity is quite low with a negative laparoscopy and appendectomy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy. On final pathology, he was found to have a 1.4-cm carcinoid tumor in the mid-appendix with direct extension to the mesoappendix, negative margins, and no lymphovascular invasion. What is the best treatment plan?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Carcinoid tumors between 1 and 1.9 cm must be treated based on the risk of recurrence. Poor prognostic indicators include high-grade lesions with a high mitotic rate, direct extension into the mesoappendix, lymph node involvement, lymphovascular invasion, positive margins, or mucin-producing tumors. If any of these are present, a formal right hemicolectomy is warranted. Octreotide is used for metastatic disease, and chemotherapy has very limited benefit for either local or metastatic carcinoid tumors
